1:30 - Why do we age, why does our body decay? Well, because otherwise evolution wouldn't work. Resources are finite. If we'd last forever, this planet couldn't accommodate our descendants. As a consequence: the planet wouldn't be able to accommodate us, as there would be no room left with all the early life still crawling around. Death, unfortunately, is the only way a species is able to adapt to new circumstances, which in turn is the only way the species is able to survive long term. Or to put it succinctly: short term death is necessary for long term survival.

That said, nothing suggests it's impossible for a species to gain immortality and yet survive through the aeons. It would only require the species to become advanced enough to compensate for what it now lacks from nature. We already do that to an extent: we have airplanes so we can fly, even though nature never provided for wings in our body plan. More relevant to this question: we have medicine to stave off disease and live longer. This is a precursor to even more advanced medicine and technology that has the potential to prolong our lifespans even more.

The greater portion of increased life expectancy came from just two factors: better sanitation, and antibiotics. We've maxed out the first and the second is fading due to over-use of antibiotics leading to highly resistant bacteria. All other factors are negligible. Furthermore, as people become even more indolent and even more obese, life expectancy in the West is actually - for the first time in history outside of war zones - decreasing due to a huge increase in lifestyle-associated diseases. There is thus no reason for optimism regarding any further meaningful extension of the human lifespan. Furthermore, why would we wish to extend life at huge cost when most people simply sleepwalk through it anyway?

Actually, ageing is vastly more complicated than telomere shortening. Yes, immortality of cells is dependent on telomeres not shortening. But there is a huge difference between individual cells and organisms, where cells must grow, proliferate and die in a harmonious fashion. Unlimited cellular replication leads to cancer. Mice, for instance, have much longer telomeres than humana t 50 kilo bases compared to only 7-10 for adult humans, and yet mice live, on average, only 2 years compared to humans who live 40 X longer. In fact, a kew charactersitic of long-lived species are short telomeres. Bowhead whales, for instead, the longest-lived mammals, with a life expectancy of at least 210 years and potentially as much as 270 years, have an average telomere length of 9 kilobases. Hydras are "immortal" because their telomeres never shorten. But, the problem is, when a hydra divides it essentiually "dies" as it becomes two individuals. Or cells also "die" when they divide, as they become two new cells as the parent cell ceases to exist. So there is an issue of semantics here. It depends a lot on your defition of the word "immortality". In complex organisms such as humans, cellular immortality is a bad thing because our cells need to divide in precise cycles, and they must self-destroy when(via apoptosis or necrosis) when they have DNA damage that is too severe to be repaired. Otherwise, cancer.

This video is a dramatic ovrsimplification. In long-lived species such as humans and bowhead whales, telomeres are kept short for cancer-prevention reasons, and the body makes up for that with a alower rate of cellular division, more efficient repair of DNA, and higher levels of antioxidants like catalase and superoxide dismutase to protect the short telomeres from corrosion, as well as stem cell reserves to replace the cells that get killed by out immune systems when their telomeres get too short.

If your telomerase were activated and you experienced no telomere shortening, it would be disastrous. Immortality? No, you would become a huge ball of tumors and die a horrible death. .

Recent breakthroughs in the area of telomere research relating to the lengthening of telomeres are very interesting because the research is moving rapidly and much that we thought we knew about telomerase is clearly incorrect. The primary concern with the lengthening of telomeres used to lie in the theoretically elevated risk of cancer but this problem does not apply based on the current research which you can see on the Stanford University website at the link at the bottom (1), as a researcher in aging I consider this work and some supporting and complementary research which has taken place at Harvard coupled with a additional research relating to the removal of senescent cells (3) tends to indicate that we are finally making significant progress in addressing the diseases of aging. Interestingly shortening of telomeres was until recently perceived by many as being a result of aging and not causal but the research at Stanford clearly repudiates this and suggests that Dr Bill Andrews (2) was correct all the way along.

The problem with average life expectancy in pre-20th century times is the word average.
It is true the average length of human life might have been slightly over 30yrs but it doesn't mean there were only 20something old people running around with some occasional 45 year old grampa. The reality is that if you lived long enough to build your immune system, which means surviving your first 10-12 years of life, you were actually very likely to live to your 60s or even 70s. Not at birth though.
There was extremely high mortality rate among children under 10years of age and giving birth was also risky as hell for women. And since kids tended to die quite a lot, women had to have more kids which meant that a lot of women died between their 20 and 30. It should be also noted that people in cities tended to suffer more from diseases since sanitation and hygiene were highly challenging in such places and the cause of diseases was not well understood.

Derek, I watched your TED video and I was wondering if you have accounted for the Monty Hall Problem in your research? What if the confused subjects chose to switch their answer, just because they were no longer convinced about their preconceptions? For example, if 1/3 choose the correct answer (a) and 2/3 choose the wrong one (b or c), then if the video confuses the subjects who chose wrong, then 50% of those subjects would end up choosing the right option (a) just by chance alone, because they switch. The people who had the right preconception are likely to allready understand the physics problem. So in effect you end up with roughly 2/3 choosing the right answer, dispite any learning actually taking place.

I'd recommend reading about HeLa cells. They're cells taken, unknowingly, from a cancer patient, Henrietta Lacks, in the '50s. They're still alive in laboratories and are basically immortal as long as they're kept in proper conditions. Unfortunately, her family has only recently been given any control over their mother's cells as the samples were taken and used for research without anyone's knowledge or consent.

Despite the ethical concerns, which are very real, HeLa cells have been used for researching diseases like polio and various cancers.

At 3:43 Derek asks how to stop the telomeres from shortening - as if they would prevent aging. But telomeres do not have anything to do with aging. They are simply an indication of aging and not the cause. They are effectively like the idiot light in your car that goes on when something goes wrong like running out of gas. Trying to keep the telomeres from shortening would be like trying to keep the idiot light running even after you ran out of gas and the battery died. The real source of the car no longer working is that there is no more gas. Fix the gas problem and the car keeps on going. As of yet, we do not know what causes aging. Also, you mention that there is one animal that never ages - the lobster. Sorry, but the lobster DOES age, just very slowly. The only animal known to man that can theoretically live forever is the immortal jellyfish. Derek, you need to do better homework before making your videos.

The 30 year average life expectancy is a bit misleading

Yes the AVERAGE lifespan was 30, but that's mostly because of high infant mortality and disease

Aristotle, who lived in the 4th century BC, was in his 60's when he died (and his death wasn't natural) and people in that time actually did live well into their 70's

Modern medicine and nutrition may have doubled the average lifespan (by reducing death by disease and injury) but has done very little to increase natural lifespan

We've pretty much hit a wall, I'm not saying that we can't overcome it, but future advancements in longevity will come a lot slower than they have in the past, since we are now actually increasing lifespan, as opposed to reducing deaths, we have to go about it in a completely different way

If you look at how life expectancy has developed since 1995 in western countries, these formulas will give you a pretty good indication of how long you can expect to live (B is the year you were born):

Males:
((B - 465.75) / 0.73) - B

Females:
((B - 525.50) / 0.70) - B

Example: Female born in 1986

Life expectancy = ((1986 - 525.50) / 0.70) - 1986
= ((1460.5) / 0.70) - 1986
= (2086.43) - 1986
= 100.43

So, if you're a female born in 1986 and live in a western country, your life expectancy is around 100 years with respect to the development during the last 20 years. This, however, is much more realistic than the current life expectancy rates, since these would only make sense if they froze/stabilized right now, in 2015, and didn't evolve at all from here on to the end of the universe.

Cancer cells do not have long telomeres they actually have short telomeres. When telomerase is expressed in cancer cells it only maintains the telomeres at a short length. Many naturally occuring cancer cells automatically extend telomere as part of the mutation. We have another more important defense against cancer. Many genes control the single cell itself's size, so that a single cell never becomes big enough to divide. Yes, you heard that right. Genes control a cell's size to an starved size. Any extra suger or ATP stored in protein structure is converted to inert fat. And that is what determines an average joe's muscle tone.
Evolution determines that humans live long and develop technology, and all protein structures ,including muscle cells, are in constant starvation mode to prevent any cell from becoming cancer cell.
That is why exercise and diet has very limited effect in shaping your body. Arnold Schewaznegger's muscles are all grown with injected testosterone hormones.

Medicine has not actually done much to date to extend human lifespans.  It has done a lot to reduce premature death; but absent something killing you, people tend to live to an age somewhere between 70 and 120 years largely based on their genetics.  (Presumably good Telomeres).  The maximum lifespan, absent some external cause of death, really has not changed much, if at all, since...ever.  The increase in "average" life expectancy has largely dropped because of massively reduced infant mortality, and to a lesser extent due to the prevention of death by disease and or accident/violence.  The research that it looks like they are going to discuss in the show that is being promoted sounds like it is intended to actually extend the maximum lifespan.

Most Biologists will tell you that telomere shortening and organismal aging can be correlated, but is not likely causative. The Hayflick Limit is a great indicator to tell you how many passages you can make of differentiated cells in tissue culture (in vitro) but ignores the fact that most tissue is not replaced through mitosis of differentiated cells in vivo. Tissue cells are replaced with adult stem cells that have active telomerase.

In more cases, mitochondria, for lack of a better term, wear out. They get to a point where they cannot replicate efficiently anymore and the cells have less mitochondria in them to produce ATP, which is the energy currency of the cell. This is especially problematic for cells that have high energy demands, such as neurons and muscle cells. It is the loss of mitochondria that is hypothesized to be at the root cause of some of the age-related neurodegenerative diseases.

Even 100 years ago people could get very old. The problem was many people died in diseases which kept the average life expectancy very low. By advances in medicine and diseases treatment we could drastically minimize the number of people dying at young age in common and simple diseases and thereby increasing life expectancy. But those advances in medicine brought also a negative side. Some of that extended life is by keeping people alive via over medication.

People that maybe should die a natural death are kept alive but with very low life quality by consuming a big number of different medications for many years, sometimes decades. Personally I think the natural life expectancy is somewhere around 65-70 years. Those last 10 years are stretching it and are done by over medication.

Yes, cancer cells have long telomeres, but they are mainly harmful because of the way they ignore the signals for cells to stop dividing, so it would still be possible to regulate the amount of cell division in our bodies but also keep our telomeres long so that our cells keep dividing. It is just a matter of cell division management and how fast the cells in our bodies divide.

I think a better alternative than to halt biological aging is to develop technology that can transfer our consciousness into machines and beyond. And I certainly believe that is more feasible than to work on all the cells at the cellular level while cells are functioning in-vivo and being interdependent with each other. Neural mapping is much simpler and we are pretty close to understanding the human mind/brain as a physical network.

The biggest problem with immortality for humans isn't just population overflow, but more importantly evolutionary hindrance.

The reason why you have to die is because the human species must stay competitive with micro-organisms and viruses. If people stop dying and reproducing (stop reproducing to avoid overpopulation), then it will slow or even staunch the genetic evolution of our defenses against the ever dying and breeding microbes and viruses.

The only way to attain immortality is beyond simply changing telomeres, we would have to change our very cells. The extracellular-matrix, for instance, would have to change in order to render the active sites of pathogens inactive, but doing this would be the equivalent of changing our very species, its trans-humanism and beyond.
Telomerase is also active in humans, but not for somatic cells.

That whole thing about life expectancy being around 30 in the past doesn't actually mean that most people died around age 30. And it isn't like 30-year-olds back then were like 80-year-olds are today. That's the average life expectancy, and what the lower number really comes from is the much higher infant mortality rate in the past. Back then, if you survived infancy and made it to adulthood, you had a pretty good chance of living a long life. Today, with modern medicine, birth and infancy isn't nearly as risky.

I always figured humans aged because we evolved to do so. It may not work out well for the individual, but if you look at it from a group evolutionary perspective it makes sense.

If no one aged or died then resources would run thin. If the old outlived the young, then they wouldn't be able to adapt or change as effectively because they are still using the same old genetics. Think of each human as one of those skin cells. The old ones need to be shed and replaced by younger generations for the system to work.

Henceforth, aging.

Senescent cells are rare even in old people - they cause problems through the rest of the body by being dysfunctional, the whole body doesn't slowly become formed out of senescent cells, as the misleading naming (and misleading Q/A in the video) may imply.

Shortening telomeres are just one of the problems that cause aging, and not necessarily even the most important for our health and well being. I wish this video didn't portray it as the only cause of aging.

There are several other forms of aging damage, and they'll all have to be solved to significantly extend our ages. For a detailed understanding, I recommend Dr. Aubrey de Grey's book, "Ending Aging: The Rejuvenation Breakthroughs That Could Reverse Human Aging in Our Lifetime".
While the rise and creation of anti aging and cybernetic technology is certainly exciting, the idea of it being available to normal people like us is very unlikely to me.

Yes, people in the middle ages had a bigger lifespan than 30 years, but due to big infant mortality rates, the average time of one's lifespan will be diminished because the average goes as following:
Take a group of x people born around the same year and that already died;
Sum together the total amount of years lived by every individual in said group;
Divide the result by x.

It's not strictly true that medical science has extended our life expectancy. All it has done is allow a greater of people to live out a full human lifespan. The lifespan itself has stayed exactly the same. Also, the statistic you quoted at the beginning--that before the industrial revolution life expectancy was somewhere in the 30s--is entirely misleading. This is because it doesn't correct for child mortality. Most people died before the age of 3. Thus, if you made it to adulthood, you could expect to live about as long as one of us. You faced greater risk of violence or disease than us, but my point is that there were plenty of old people around, and people in their 30s were certainly not considered old or nearing the end of their lifespan.

A few things I've heard about our increasing life expectancy.

First. The much lower average life spans of the past was due mostly to the much higher infant mortality rate. Which, when added to the equation, brought the average down. It is believed that if you managed to survive past that point you could expect to live maybe 50 or 60 years or more.

Second. Evan though our average life span is getting higher in our times, the oldest people in each generation don't seem to be getting any older. There seems to be a maximum age "wall" at about 110 to 120 years. All our increased life expectancy seems to be doing is approaching that maximum.

Then again, these are just things that I've heard. Let me know what you think.

Logic behind ageing is pretty simple:
How do you keep a machinery working for long long time?...Either by making it indestructible, which doesn't fit in with the way universe works wherein everything is meant to be broken (2nd law of thermodynamics!), or by replacing the worn parts with new parts every now and then. Following the feasible way and replenishing the cells every now n then, our body tries its best to keep the replication procedure as error proof as it could be (DNA replication machinery has so many safeguard mechanisms which do in fact ensure efficiency of 1 in a billion chance of error but the fact that it has to make 3 billion of such operations every time a cell divides renders it far from being perfect). So what happens when these errors keep accumulating in the cell's DNA sequence generation after generation? If one is lucky the errors might simply kill those cells or render them unable to divide or perform their functions etc. Or it might lead to cancer when these cells escape the mechanisms that keeps them from dividing. So one can say that if you live long enough you are bound to have cancer. Ageing is the mechanism that tells the cells not to divide any more after a limit coz it might simply bring more bad than good. So it seems like ageing was the nature's way to extend our lifetimes.

Actually the life expectacy and avrage life span is not the same.

Avarage life span is the life expactancy at birth. As people get older the life expectacy raise.

For example for a person that is 90 years old the life expectancy must be higher than 80 years.

The reason why avarage life span back in the days was that low was not because people died when they was 30, but because half died when they was infants and the other half lived to about 60. This make the avrage life span of 30 years.

When child mortality lowered the average life span increased quite a lot just because child mortality decreased. In the 1900:eds child mortality in west is quite close to 0%. So the average life expectancy is about the same from birth as it is 20 years later.

The actual increase in life span from 60 to about 80 years is not that big and is mostly due to better living conditions and safer every day life. Of cause, better emergency health care is part of this. Cancer treatment also raise the average life span, but not really that much.

You might imagine that better medicine help life expectancy quite a lot... and it would have, but this really to a large degree offset by more disease going around.

There is also life shortening things like obesity and heart disease that was almost a non issue 100 years ago. This ofset quite a bit of the gain we get from cancer treatment and medicine. Also smoking is part of this. When smoking become a every person thing this really shorten the life expectancy, but this was during war times, so people just didnt care.

I have 2 problems with the Thesis of this video, i would like some clarifications:
1: A low average life is not necessarily associated with everyone dying at 35, it can be a sign of high infant mortality: If half the population dies at 5 and the survivors get to 65, the average life span is also 35, but telomeres have no role in the mortality rate. Death at very young age is a more convincing cause for that average, given what we know about life in the wild w/o medicine and technology.

2: The idea that we developed this mechanism to fight cancer is peculiar. We stop reproducing WAY before we reach an age when cancer and telomere shortening become an issue, so there would be little advantage to give up immortality to fight cancer. It makes more sense from an evolutionary standpoint to consider this just another "error" that evolution has no intrest in correcting because when old age becomes a problem, the individual either already reproduced or doesn't deserve to because is not fit. Finally, you need a generational change to introduce improvement in the gene pool, and immortality would result in a great deal of individual carrying the same genes around forever, with no improvement at all.

A few thoughts:
10,000 years ago the average human life lasted just over 30 years because many people died in childhood. Bring down infant mortality, and the average life statistic goes up greatly. For instance, also 10,000 years ago, if you made it to age 15, then your life expectancy at that point would be 54 rather than 33. That is to say, out of all people who survived to their 15th birthday, the average age at which they died was 54. It is true, however, that people live longer now than they did then, it's just slightly less impressive to go from 54 to 80 than from 33 to 80.

People who are interested in aging, how it works and how we might be able to slow it down would probably enjoy reading David Gems. He uses C. elegans as a model organism to study aging. I attended one of his lectures in...I think January. He can be a bit strident with his proclamations that "Old age is a disease and we should cure it!" but his work is quite interesting.
